DataElement.preferredName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire 8 Last 24 Hours How Much Relief Received from Treatment or Medication Score 11 Point Percent Likert Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated observation of how much relief pain treatment or medication has provided in the last 24 hours, using a 11 point Likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire Last 24 Hours How Much Relief Received from Treatment or Medication Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A standardized survey originally developed and copyrighted by Charles S. Cleeland in 1991 which is used to evaluate the severity of a patient's pain and the impact that their pain has on their daily activities. This shorter version of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) is more useful for clinical trials, can be completed by the patient or in an interview format, and consists of only 9 questions most of which can be answered on a 0-10 rating scale._Coming after all others in time or space or degree or being the only one remaining._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::24_A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day._A question about how much pain relief an individual is receiving or has received from treatment or medication._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A standardized survey originally developed and copyrighted by Charles S. Cleeland in 1991 which is used to evaluate the severity of a patient's pain and the impact that their pain has on their daily activities. This shorter version of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) is more useful for clinical trials, can be completed by the patient or in an interview format, and consists of only 9 questions most of which can be answered on a 0-10 rating scale.

Concepts.longName: Brief Pain Inventory Short Form Questionnaire
Concepts.definition: A standardized survey originally developed and copyrighted by Charles S. Cleeland in 1991 which is used to evaluate the severity of a patient's pain and the impact that their pain has on their daily activities. This shorter version of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) is more useful for clinical trials, can be completed by the patient or in an interview format, and consists of only 9 questions most of which can be answered on a 0-10 rating scale.

Property.preferredName: Last Integer::24 Hour How Much Relief Received from Treatment or Medication Score
Property.preferredDefinition: Coming after all others in time or space or degree or being the only one remaining.:A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::24:In modern usage, an hour is defined as a unit of time 60 minutes, or 3600 seconds in length. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.:A question about how much pain relief an individual is receiving or has received from treatment or medication.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: Coming after all others in time or space or degree or being the only one remaining.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.

Concepts.longName: How Much Relief Received from Treatment or Medication
Concepts.definition: A question about how much pain relief an individual is receiving or has received from treatment or medication.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

ValueDomain.preferredName: BPI Percentage Relief From Pain Treatment or Medication Score 11 Point Likert Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An ordered reference standard for the subjective scoring of the percentage of relief from pain medication or treatment that ranges from 0%: No Relief to 100%: Complete Relief.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Quality of Life Measures (Patient Reported Outcomes - Health Related Quality of Life)

ReferenceDocuments.name: In the last 24 hours, how muc
ReferenceDocuments.description: In the last 24 hours, how much relief have pain treatments or medications provided? Please circle the one percentage that shows how much RELIEF you have received.

ReferenceDocuments.name: BPI User's Guide
ReferenceDocuments.description: Documentation of the BPI's development and psychometric properties.

ReferenceDocuments.name: BPI SF
ReferenceDocuments.description: In the last 24 hours, how much relief have pain treatments or medications provided? Please circle the one percentage that shows how much RELIEF you have received. (8)

ReferenceDocuments.name: Using PRO/HRQoL Measures
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data element is part of a full set of items that comprise a PRO/HRQoL measure. The full set must be used without any changes to the questions or value set in order to retain the validity and reliability associated with the measure. The URL citation is provided so that caDSR users can obtain materials related to instructions for administering and/or scoring the measure. Changes may not be made to these documents. Where an investigator wants to use single Patient Reported Outcome items that are integrated into a study, DCP review is required prior to inclusion of the item on a case report form.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Medidata ePRO CDE
ReferenceDocuments.description: This CDE has been validated for use with the Medidata Rave ePRO module.
